newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine gov't, unions near deal on reforms - paper.
newsitem.headline: Argentine gov't, unions near deal on reforms - paper.

text.p: The Argentine government and the labor federation CGT have resumed key talks on proposed labor reforms and health-care deregulation and hope to strike a deal this month, the daily Clarin said Friday.
Quoting congressional sources, the paper said President Carlos Menem was following progress closely and officials hoped consensus could be reached as early as next Tuesday.
The government believes an accord with the unions, which adamantly oppose the labor reform plans and have staged strikes this year, will ease the bill's passage through a reluctant Congress.
Clarin quoted government sources as saying Menem, although buoyed by the talks, has told his aides that if necessary he will still pass the labor reforms by presidential decree.
Contact between unions and the government had broken down and the CGT held a 24-hour general strike in August and a 36-hour strike in September.
Menem hopes the package of laws, which would end collective bargaining and replace compensation payments for dismissal with unemployment insurance, will cut Argentina's 17.1-percent joblessness rate.
The CGT also opposes government plans to deregulate the unions-run health care system from January 1997 to allow the free choice of health system and the participation of private companies from 1998.
